7. What’s now been happening for nearly a year at the homes of Supreme Court justices is illegal. And it’s dangerous. The Department of Justice needs to ENFORCE 1507 in these cases—not thwart enforcement!

6. Garland’s insistence  (echoed today by Monaco) that Marshals have “full authority to arrest” people protesting at the homes of justices cannot be reconciled with the instructions given to Marshals, which appear deliberately designed to discourage if not preclude such arrests.

5. Deputy A.G. Monaco said she had not reviewed the training materials before the Marshals were given these instructions. Nor has she since asked for them to be changed or discussed them with A.G. Garland.

4. The training materials also instruct Marshals that they should coordinate any contemplated arrest under 1507 “in advance with the appropriate U.S. Attorney’s Office,” which will effectively halt any effort to enforce this law in this context, which the law clearly covers.

3. Those training materials falsely tell the Marshals that to make such an arrest, the protestors’ conduct must include “criminal threats and intimidation.” This is contrary to the plain text of 1507, which requires only that protesters act “with intent of influencing any judge.”

2. Three weeks after Garland told me that in early March, @KatieBrittforAL asked him about training materials given to U.S. Marshals LIMITING their authority to make such arrests under 1507. Garland said he knew nothing about them, even though they contradict what he told me.

Estoy agradecido con todos los líderes políticos y comunitarios, residentes, organizaciones y expertos legales que contribuyeron a este proyecto de ley. Espero regresar a Puerto Rico para continuar discusiones sobre este importante tema.

El gobierno federal tiene una responsabilidad de facilitar la descolonización de Puerto Rico y la gente de Puerto Rico merece la oportunidad de hacer una decisión informada y democrática hacia el estatus polِítico de la isla.
Y, en contraste con los plebiscitos anteriores, requiere que el Congreso implemente la opción seleccionada por la mayoría de los votos.

Es importante destacar que el proyecto de ley también describe la transición y la implementación de cada opción de estatus político, contestando preguntas clave sobre el futuro de la isla y sus residentes.

El proyecto de ley establecería un plebiscito federal en la isla con tres opciones de estatus político no territoriales y totalmente autónomo: Estadidad, Soberanía en Libre Asociación con los Estados Unidos e Independencia.

El proyecto de Ley para el Estatus de Puerto Rico es un proyecto histórico que establece un proceso para la gente de Puerto Rico para finalmente lograr la autodeterminación y la descolonización de la isla.

Mañana estaré reintroduciendo el proyecto de Ley para el Estatus de Puerto Rico junto con @NydiaVelazquez, @RepJenniffer, @RepDarrenSoto, @RepAOC, @RepStenyHoyer y @RepRitchie. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FuGeg7lXsAEPUeY.png

I am grateful to all the political and community leaders, residents, organizations, and legal experts who contributed to this bill. I look forward to returning to Puerto Rico to continue discussions on this important subject.

The federal government has a responsibility to facilitate the decolonization of Puerto Rico and the people of Puerto Rico deserve an opportunity to make a democratic and informed choice on the island’s ultimate political status.

Importantly, the bill describes the transition to and implementation of each status option, answering key questions about the future of the island and its residents. And, unlike past plebiscites, Congress would be required to implement the choice that a majority of voters make.

The bill would establish a federal plebiscite on the island with three non-territorial, fully self-governing status options on the ballot: Statehood, Sovereignty in Free Association with the United States, and Independence.
The Puerto Rico Status Act is a historic bill that lays out a process for the people of Puerto Rico to once and for all achieve self-determination and decolonization.

Tomorrow, I will re-introduce the Puerto Rico Status Act alongside @NydiaVelazquez, @RepJenniffer, @RepDarrenSoto, @RepAOC, @RepStenyHoyer, and @RepRitchie. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FuGcwzeWwAQiTXy.png

On to decoms. Accelerating the retirement of CGs like Vicksburg remains baffling when our undersea vertical launch system capacity, surface VLS capacity, and torpedo capacity are all set to decline between now and 2030. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FuGsqEYWIAMUW2T.jpg

SSNs: Within the Davidson window, each of the 3 alternatives results in our attack submarine fleet contracting to 48 subs by FY26 and only Alternative 2 reaches the requirement of 66 attack subs by FY49.

Frigates: By failing to max out the FFG-62 production line, the Navy will prevent the potential award of a second frigate yard which both undermines the fleet as it shifts to more distributed operations with smaller platforms and constrains the industrial base long-term.

Destroyers: While Alternative 3 was built without funding constraints, it was based on "what the Department assess the industrial base could support," which does not include 3 destroyers until FY36 at the earliest, but Congress bought 3 DDGs last year.

Amphibs: The FY23 NDAA set a floor of 31 traditional L-class amphibs for the USMC. Disregarding the law, none of the 3 alternatives would reach this minimum between now and FY53. This is strange since Alternative 3 was built "without funding constraints."http://cq.com
